abstract.p: Letter by environmental scientist Robert S Dischel says that Bill McKibben's May 3 Op-Ed article convicts man-made carbon dioxide of causing global warming before scientific facts are all in evidence; points out that short-term events prove nothing, since Northern Hemisphere has had many periods of cooling and warming temperatures (S)

block.p: Bill McKibben, in his denunciation of political and industry irresponsibility (Op-Ed, May 3), sentences the accused -- man-made carbon dioxide -- before the jury has reached its verdict. He cites recent weather trends as proof of change, and would have us accept that ''cars, factories and burning forests'' cause global warming.

Bill McKibben, in his denunciation of political and industry irresponsibility (Op-Ed, May 3), sentences the accused -- man-made carbon dioxide -- before the jury has reached its verdict. He cites recent weather trends as proof of change, and would have us accept that ''cars, factories and burning forests'' cause global warming.

Short-term events prove nothing. In the Northern Hemisphere, over a thousand centuries, there have been long periods of expanding glaciers, interrupted by shorter periods of warming. We are in a warm period, yet the average temperature for the longer epoch is frigid. We need only look back a dozen millenniums to remember the kilometer-thick glacier that rests on the very spot where we stand.

Scientists don't know what causes climate shifts; we only understand governing physical principles. Climate depends on interactions so complex as to make forecasts, and hindcasts, no more than reasoned guesses.

While emissions may affect the climate, constraints on them certainly affect the economy. We must be careful not to leap over logic: when we elevate human significance in the arena of global influence, we may be making a self-important, and self-deluding, statement of our potency.
ROBERT S. DISCHEL New York, May 3, 1997
The writer is an environmental scientist.
